articles.headline: Links in 7-Eleven’s Chain Threaten to Snap as Store Owners Balk at Contract
articles.snippet: Tensions between 7-Eleven and its franchisees have simmered for years. Now, they’re boiling over as store owners face a new franchise agreement that they say will shrink their profits further.
articles.abstract: Tensions between 7-Eleven and its franchisees have simmered for years. Now, they’re boiling over as store owners face a new franchise agreement that they say will shrink their profits further.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s known for its Slurpees and Big Gulps, but over the years, 7-Eleven has also put its logo on frozen pizza, foam cups, laundry detergent and hundreds of other products.

articles.headline: In Florida, Not All Politics Are Local, as Trump Shapes Governor’s Race
articles.snippet: The president’s endorsement of Ron DeSantis in the Republican primary has tipped the race in his favor and shown how unwavering support of Mr. Trump can be crucial.
articles.abstract: The president’s endorsement of Ron DeSantis in the Republican primary has tipped the race in his favor and shown how unwavering support of Mr. Trump can be crucial.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — The Sarasota County Republican fair and rally last Saturday left little mystery about what is animating the party this year.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Mulls a Unilateral Tax Cut for the Rich
articles.snippet: A proposal under consideration at the Treasury Department would bypass Congress and use federal regulation to index capital gains for inflation, a $100 billion boost for high earners.
articles.abstract: A proposal under consideration at the Treasury Department would bypass Congress and use federal regulation to index capital gains for inflation, a $100 billion boost for high earners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is considering bypassing Congress to grant a $100 billion tax cut mainly to the wealthy, a legally tenuous maneuver that would cut capital gains taxation and fulfill a long-held ambition of many investors and conservatives.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Les Moonves Stays as CBS C.E.O. While Its Board Plans an Investigation
articles.snippet: Days after The New Yorker detailed allegations of sexual harassment against Mr. Moonves, the company’s directors took no immediate action.
articles.abstract: Days after The New Yorker detailed allegations of sexual harassment against Mr. Moonves, the company’s directors took no immediate action.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leslie Moonves, the embattled chief executive of CBS Corporation, survived the meeting.

articles.headline: Manafort’s Trial Isn’t About Russia, but It Will Be in the Air
articles.snippet: The trial of Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, concerns his work as a consultant in Ukraine. But the Russia inquiry looms over the proceedings.
articles.abstract: The trial of Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, concerns his work as a consultant in Ukraine. But the Russia inquiry looms over the proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When they present their evidence in the financial fraud trial of Paul Manafort beginning this week, federal prosecutors have promised the judge, no government witness will even utter the word Russia.

articles.headline: T-Mobile and Sprint: How Fewer Competitors Could Increase Competition
articles.snippet: Conventional wisdom says the two companies should be blocked from merging to preserve competition and benefit consumers. But the merger could actually create a mightier maverick.
articles.abstract: Conventional wisdom says the two companies should be blocked from merging to preserve competition and benefit consumers. But the merger could actually create a mightier maverick.
articles.lead_paragraph: There has been no shortage of opinions about the proposed merger of T-Mobile and Sprint. Just about the only person who hasn’t said something is President Trump.

articles.headline: Key Question for Les Moonves of CBS: What Were You Thinking?
articles.snippet: Mr. Moonves started a civil war by suing the network’s controlling shareholder while knowing that harassment allegations were swirling.
articles.abstract: Mr. Moonves started a civil war by suing the network’s controlling shareholder while knowing that harassment allegations were swirling.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New Yorker’s account of sexual harassment allegations against CBS’s chief executive, Leslie Moonves, has many disturbing echoes of what has become a long list of predatory behavior by corporate executives.

articles.headline: Judge Blocks Attempt to Post Blueprints for 3-D Guns
articles.snippet: Cody Wilson, a Texas champion of gun rights and anarchists, had said he would post blueprints for 3-D printed plastic guns on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Cody Wilson, a Texas champion of gun rights and anarchists, had said he would post blueprints for 3-D printed plastic guns on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, Cody Wilson, a champion of gun-rights and anarchism from Texas, has waged a battle to post on the internet the blueprints for making plastic guns on 3-D printers, claiming the First Amendment gives him the right to do it.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Tiffany Hsu and Kirk Johnson
